content: Renaming tag to "Reading the statement" because I don't want to be associated with aCat's "read a textbook outside of the statement" nonsense.

The way the problem is worded, I feel that 7 is possible :
- replace two fruit by an apple and five by an orange
- replace the apple by a watermelon and the orange by a watermelon
- replace both watermelon by an apple
- replace the apple by a watermelon => win
I don't think you need the watermelons. Instead, if you end a turn with only one fruit left, you win.
I think the 'swap roles' part is irrelevant, is it intentional? :)

The `n` is undefined. Providing I understood, what about:

each one matches a bundle of exactly n pieces in the first line, where n depends on the fruit type (see below).

And then:

- apples, that spread one for every bundle of two (n = 2)
- ...
I bet that Reading Comprehension will again be an issue ^^, but whatever, nice story.

Also about the tests:

- The "Easy Victories" test should be paired with its own validator consisting only of victories (and likewise for the "Easy Defeats" test)
- You can probably put "Beginner's Mix" and "Cocktail Adventurer" together as a test-validator pair
- Validator "Tutti Frutti" could use some defeats to match its corresponding test :)

I liked the problem after I figured out what to do. While the story is nice, the statement is a bit unclear:

- I wasn't sure what the "stock" was when I first read it.
- The variable n is only referenced once, so it's unclear what it's referring to.
- I didn't understand how there could be fruit "left over" in the first line if no fruit was ever removed from it while building the second line.
- I didn't understand how fruit from the first line could be "scooped to the blender" if there are no fruit left over on the first line.

The examples definitely helped (especially since they used the word "replace" instead of the word "spread"), but I felt that they could have been illustrated more graphically, perhaps somewhat like this:

FFFFF FFFFF FFFFF
B B B
O
W

Comforting that you doubted "stock": I did too. Do you have a suggestion?

About [[n]], yeah, I see what you mean. Same sentence: do you have suggestion?

Mmmm the "leftover" I do have a rewrite idea, I'll try that. That ought to solve the next point too.

Yeah, I voluntarily sidestepped the guidelines.
The point is to get the easy to debug cases in the tests, but to make the validators harder to guess (not solve).

So they're not strictly paired anymore, but they do test the same things _as a pair_: the two validators to the easy victories/defeats cases, test numbers that are very close, just mixed.

Tutti Frutti... I've my doubts. It's kind of easy to "pass", but I did update the stub so it does *not* come up as solved upon first try.
What can I say. I'm in the literary phase of my life /o\

It is (as far as the game is concerned), just as much as eating the fruit or blending it is.

But you made me notice it could help understand why those names were chosen.

Or maybe not.

I'm not quite sure how you'd get that impression. 

The statement says “you pick *a* fruit type”. “One apple and one orange” in your first step is not *a* fruit type.

You don't get to replace just any amount of fruit you'd like!
